author: mililani
body:
I saw the reversal mid after noon and was like, ok, looks like the market is coming back from this.  Found it was the Fed announce 1.5 trillion USD of liquidity injections.  Then the market went *BAM*, fuck you FEDS!  We're sick of your bullshit!  And dropped back down and closed by another -1300 pts! 

If you haven't been paying attention, that's some scary shit!  The Fed had an emergency meeting and dropped a 50 bps cut.  Then it expanded repo market operations from 100 to 150 to 175 billion dollars in a few weeks.  And now they announced 1.5 trillion USD of liquidity injections, and the market just steam rolled RIGHT past that.  Just like, "Yeah, fuck you this time.  You guys ain't gonna do shit!"  If that doesn't make you wake up and realize this is WAY different than 07/08, you need to get your head outta your ass.  No amount of gov't intervention is going to rescue this market now.

author: zg44
body:
Let me explain why a bottom can come sooner even as the news is getting worse and we still don't know the real numbers:

Because now with that NBA news and Tom Hanks news, everybody in the US will take this seriously and treat it as if our real numbers are similar to Italy.

So within the next few days, if we see a complete panic, we could end up pricing in the worst scenario instead of just a range of scenarios with some hopeful outcomes baked in...

By next week, I'm thinking markets could be very bleak and that means we could get to the point where even the real numbers won't spook markets.

Just some thoughts on the process of bottoming.  It's just important to try to be nimble around these things; markets typically bottom when bearish sentiment reaches its peak and that will happen well before the coronavirus actually peaks in the US.

author: Honkycatt
body:
Here ya go:

>	Robinhood Maxed Out Credit Line Last Month Amid Market Tumult

>	In the throes of frantic market uncertainty, traders using Robinhood Markets Inc. faced the ultimate frustration: Their accounts kept malfunctioning. Behind the scenes, the online brokerage was already bracing for financial strains.

>	Robinhood drew its entire $200 million credit facility from Barclays Plc, Citigroup Inc. and JPMorgan Chase & Co., according to people familiar with the matter. It made the move just as fears of the coronavirus set off more than two weeks of violent market swings and heavy volume, during which Robinhood’s trading platform suffered three significant outages.

>	“Our capital position remains strong,” the Menlo Park, California-based firm said in an emailed statement, saying the decision to borrow predated and was entirely unrelated to the outages. “We determined it was prudent to draw on our credit line during the week of Feb. 24 in light of market volatility. That capital was returned in full last week.”

>	It said it’s not unusual for companies to take precautionary measures during such market conditions.

>	“Companies don’t tap their credit line unless they need to,” said David Ritter, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence, who spoke generally about the issue without commenting directly on Robinhood. When companies do, it’s “perhaps not a good signal with regard to their cash burn, which could make creditors nervous.”

>	Repeated Outages

>	In the days since it tapped the line of credit, Robinhood’s platform has repeatedly gone dark for more than an hour at a time, including an outage March 2 that spanned an entire U.S. trading session, in which the S&P 500 surged 4.6%.

>	Robinhood said last week that a confluence of factors -- record account sign-ups along with highly volatile and historic market conditions -- led to unprecedented stress on the firm’s infrastructure.

>	That heavy load caused the so-called Domain Name System, or DNS, to fail. The system is essentially the phone book that computers use to turn a domain name into an IP address, and it’s how users access websites around the world.

>	On Monday, Robinhood faced a fresh breakdown as U.S. stocks plunged. Stocks tumbled so hard they set off a market-wide trading halt minutes after the open. And by day’s end, the S&P 500 was down 7.6%, the worst performance since the depths of 2008’s financial crisis.

>	“We know this interruption was frustrating for our customers -- especially after last week and on a day that trading was halted,” the company said in the statement. “Our platform is now fully operational and we’re working hard to improve our service during these historic and volatile market conditions.”

>	The firm declined to comment further on what sparked Monday’s disruption.

>	Engineering Focus

>	Robinhood, founded in 2013 by Vlad Tenev and Baiju Bhatt, pioneered commission-free trading, a move that’s since been copied by larger online brokers including Charles Schwab Corp. The startup has attracted 10 million users and is now backed by venture capital firms including Index Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz and Sequoia, garnering a valuation of $7.6 billion.

>	The company has been increasingly focused on improving the reliability of its service in recent years, and in mid-2018 hired Adam Wolff from Facebook Inc. to lead its squad of engineers.

>	When Wolff joined, Robinhood’s entire engineering workforce was the size of the group of specialists he’d led at Facebook, he previously said. He has been focused on adding staff and last month hired former Facebook colleague Paul Tarjan.

>	“An area where we plan to focus is one we continue to invest in heavily as a company -- compliance,” Wolff said in a blog post announcing the hiring. “It’s fundamental to our focus on our customers and our ability to safely and confidently move forward as a firm.”

>	Shaken Confidence

>	Software mishaps have rocked Robinhood before. In late 2018, the company’s options trading service had an outage that locked consumers out of their accounts and stopped them from closing positions. Employees had to call affected clients to apologize, according to people familiar with the matter.

>	For its latest outages, Robinhood has created a dedicated customer service team to work directly with customers, the company said in a statement. The impact among customers “varies significantly due to the nature of our business,” it said.

>	The latest technology problems have drawn the attention of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, which has been in touch with Robinhood on the matter, according to a spokeswoman for the brokerage regulator. The firm previously agreed to pay $1.25 million to the watchdog for allegedly failing to ensure customers received best prices for securities orders. It didn’tadmit or deny the allegations when settling the complaint.

>	Financial technology startups can risk eroding customer trust with outages, said John Bartleman, president of TradeStationGroup Inc., a rival online trading firm.

>	“If you’re a smaller fintech startup, your reputation is everything,” he said “If you can’t get in, you lose all trust in a brand.”

>	A growing number of Robinhood users on social media have been reporting trouble with closing their accounts. They’re also criticizing the $75 fee associated with the transferring to another platform.

>	Pankaj Sharma, a New Jersey IT professional with a $70,000 Robinhood account, said he sent an email to the company when he realized the site was down March 2, but didn’t receive a response until after the market closed. He’s now considering moving his money to a different brokerage.

>	“It’s really shaken my confidence,” he said by phone.

author: DARPA1191969v1
Salty_Cornflakes
body:
For those of you wondering if COVID-19 is priced in, look at it this way:

The first big drop a couple weeks ago wasn't a response to the virus in the US, it was a delayed response to the virus damaging the supply chain in China, with maybe a hint of fear selling. Now that the virus is just ramping up in the US and parts of Europe, the demand side of the economy is going to suffer.Any companies or industries that were struggling, slowing, or on the verge of being insolvent are going to crash.

The virus' impact could be much greater in the US too. Americans suffer from an over-sized sense of independence/self-reliance which will result in a less unified response and likely allow the virus to spread further because the citizens won't allow their liberties to be infringed. Add to that a working class that has tons of debt and cant afford to take days off work and you've got yourself a nice recipe for disaster.

Factor in all the other economic data and it's hard to see how this isn't headed for a cliff.

TL;DR SPY 290P 5/15

author: performx92
body:
Let’s me share something, incase you all have short term memory loss. 

We’ve been dropping for about 3 weeks now. 
Cases are increasing on a daily basis, worldwide. 
Oil price war, biggest single day drop since 1991 today. Fed cut last week did jack shit. 
Another cruise quarantined. 
Italy has a couple of cases a week ago, it’s on lock down now. 
Supply chains are still fucked, orders backed up.
Conventions and events are getting cancelled left and right. 
Airlines suffering because people are scared to get on planes. 

Vaccines take time and the reality is we can barely get our country tested, which doesn’t help with sentiment as the mortality rate seems much higher than it really is.

Wtf do you people thing is going to happen in the near future? A bull market? Sentiment is fucking low. 

Get a grip, ride the waves if you want, but we’re not getting out of this hole in a day, it’ll take years for this all to blow over. That being said let the market take a breather for a day and enjoy the opportunities.

author: UnhandledPromise
body:
This is the same question as the one posed before the crash.

"how can these companies keep valuations which aren't reflected by balance sheets or other fundamentals?"

it's a balancing act. We are tilted far on the other end right now.

Where it will tilt next week, I wouldn't be bold enough to say. I'm out as of today with over 380% gains. Coulda been more if I had more balls but I'm happy for now to sit on the sidelines.

author: dfoolio
body:
>	Cramer turned to his trusted S&P 500 Short Range Oscillator, a subscription product now offered by MarketEdge, for an unbiased take on the markets. Any reading between +5 and -5 is neutral, he explained, while any reading greater than five means sell and below negative five means buy. There is only one other reading on the oscillator that matters, however, and that's -12. 

>	The oscillator hit -12 after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, and again at the end of 2016 and 2018 when the Fed took interest rates too far. During all of those times, a reading of -12 signaled the bottom. The only time -12 failed to be correct was in the middle of the financial crisis in 2008. Today is not 2008, Cramer said, adding there is no systemic risk to the markets. He said we will be getting a mild recession based on a lack of travel and entertainment -- so-called gatherings -- but the oscillator is saying the odds favor buying short-term -- and long-term, for that matter.

So Cramer relies on a magical oscillator to know if it’s time to buy or sell? What in the actual fuck?

author: Bartlet4America94
body:
Copying my comment regarding RH suits:

If you file in court, they’ll move to dismiss, since the “proper” venue is via a FINRA arbitration. 

A bunch of these popping up will cause headaches, but it’ll probably be a copy-paste type motion to dismiss, so it won’t cost them that much $. Lack of PJ, improper venue, even SJ since it’s all federal securities (though many states have their own securities regulatory bodies).

Now, there are jurx that don’t follow mandatory arbitration (LA, NC) so technically those RH users in these states could file and not necessarily get bumped out on the MtD phase. However, since this is mainly federal stuff, I still think most courts will defer to FINRA.

The main strategy would be to file in court and then immediately leverage settlement before the judge rules on dismissal. Settlement for each individual case would be low and so would be the bargaining power of the potential plaintiff. You’d want to consolidate all actions into a class. The problem with this is it takes time and then you’ll have fights over class cert. that can move the settlement needle back and forth.

I'm not going to even pretend that I have strong hands. I was forced to hold over the weekend by 2 personal policies I established before all this craziness:
* Don't use market orders
* Don't make decisions in panic situations

I tried to sell my SPY puts(SPXS calls) during the last 2 minutes of Friday market but the price kept falling below the limit price I set. Then I tried to find news of why the sudden SPY spike was happening. Couldn't find it and barely had 45 seconds to market close so I just gave up and said to myself: _"Whatever, I'm going down with the ship"_.

It's only now that my sinking ship is looking more like a space shuttle preparing for take off.

author: Salty_Cornflakes
body:
To all those crying about the death of WSB, here is a mod's response:

 

* We're working on it. We've made a few adjustments already that have helped immensely. I'd wager that 4/5 of the posts that you're complaining about don't even see the light of day. Which should impress and terrify you.
* It's difficult trying to strike a balance. The public attention has brought a lot of legitimate traders here who just want to share their experience, real DD, technical analysis, etc and we want to encourage that. They obviously make new accounts and we want them to contribute immediately.
* We're tweaking things everyday in response to rapidly changing growth and news that swings the entire sub in a matter of hours (like our pumping problem last week). This weeked now everyone is talking about their local Costco, committing bioterroism, and killing the pope. Also, please calm the fuck down with killing the pope, guys. It's borderline enciting violence, I've temp banned a few people who take it wayyyy too far.
* Our sexuality aside, we're volunteers from around the world. Our hours and availability differ, so there are mod lulls where a lot of one liner shitposts get through. We do our best, but we really focus on providing the best experience we can for you guys during trading hours when the engagement here is through the roof.
* As far as you or others wanting to volunteer, you guys actually do a pretty good job en mass with downvoting and reporting bullshit. Keep it up. We appreciate that.

That's all I got at the moment. Hope it gives you some kind of something.

author: Sikeitsryan
body:
since no ones helped you out

options are contracts entered into by you and someone else (a counter party). There's 2 types of options, puts and calls. If you look at OP's picture you'll see that one of his "trades" is for SQQQ $29 CALL 3/20.

So he wants to buy a call. Now, like I said this call is a contract between OP and someone else. This contract states that at anytime between the day that OP purchases the call contract and the expiration date of the contract, stated as 3/20/2020. OP has the 'option' or choice to buy 100 shares of the etf SQQQ from the counter party of the contract for $29 regardless of what the actual price of the ETF is.

&#x200B;

So theoretically, if on 3/15 SQQQ is trading at $50 a share, OP can exercise his option and buy those 100 shares for $29 dollars from the counter party and sell those shares immediately in the open market for $50. 

&#x200B;

The downside is that OP has to pay the counter party a 'premium' in order to have this option. Right now the premium has a bid/ask of $2.65 x 2.95. So if OP wants to buy the call he has to pay $2.95 x 100 (per share, remember the call gives op the right to buy 100 shares from the counter party). Now, you may be asking, why is the spread so wide? Wouldn't OP immediately lose $30 or 10% on his trade? Is OP gambling with probably zero actual insight on investing? I'll let you figure those out on your own.

author: Tairaa90
body:
Well im pretty green on the topics of stocks and business but im a PC enthusiast so there is some context here that im pretty familiar with. A year ago they had no viable offerings for a good CPU (fx was dated af and not a contender, dont tell me about the fx series as an offering) and their best GPUs were weaker and not as cost effective as nVidias. The best they had was low to medium performance options for both markets. This has been their position with respect of Intel and nVidia for a long time. Now their CPUs are king and their GPUs are competitive, even lacking a flagship as powerful as the 2080 or 2080ti. 

They have rapidly transitioned from a sustained underdog position to a real tooth and nail competitor. If we assume that this trend will continue does it not stand to reason that their share price should also continue to perform as they seize a greater market share?

This of course says nothing about server and console hardware, which im less familiar with but i hear they're doing well in those sectors as well.

author: stringfold
body:
It's not video processors where AMD's growth potential greatest -- it's in the server market, where they are currently dominating Intel in terms of performance per watt. Now, Intel is a behemoth when it comes to the server market, and they're not going to give up market share easily, but AMD is better placed to gain a substantial share of the server market from Intel now than they have ever been, and that's not hyperbole.

Video is a much tougher market position for them, with nVidia still leading substantially at the high end, and poised to release their next generation cards. AMD's limited research budget has been mostly focused on their CPU technology, as it should be, so it's going to take longer for them to catch up with nVidia, if they can at all.

author: SmallPotGuest
body: I would park, say, 25k for a few weeks to buy cheap good performing stocks like amd, nvda, msft and the such and go wild with the other 5k. You take risks, but not dumb account blowing risks so you get to enjoy the money you make instead of the promises of getting even more money out of it.

author: Summebride
body:
Go back a month and keep in mind NVDA was back to $293, its old high water mark.  Nobody knew what they would report and whether it would be ok or terrible.  Many took profits, not wanting to hold the bag if the ER was tepid.

Turns out they reported a spectacular ER and incredibly positive guidance.  In any other times, it would have vaulted into the 300's with chatter about $400.  It started, but immediately corona news and Asia gloom was the talk and instead of receiving credit for the excellent ER, NVDA has been down and down.  That may not have been fair.

author: Draiko
body:
Fun fact: The software that was used to go from raw virus sample to full atomic-level map in 12 days was built using Nvidia CUDA and runs on Nvidia T4s and V100s.

These models help with tracking genetic drift, developing effective therapeutic treatments, and developing/improving vaccines.

Gaming saves lives.

I see increased demand for Nvidia hardware in the future.
